content.card_other: Work is done when force causes displacement. Scalar quantity. Only force component parallel to displacement does work. If force is perpendicular to displacement, work is zero. SI unit: joule (J).

Positive work: Force component in direction of motion (0° ≤ θ < 90°), energy added. Negative work: Force component opposite to motion (90° < θ ≤ 180°), energy removed. Zero work: Force perpendicular to motion (θ = 90°).
The capacity to do work. Scalar quantity. Same units as work (joule). Various forms: kinetic, potential, thermal, chemical, nuclear, electrical, etc.
Energy possessed by a body due to its motion. Depends on mass and square of velocity. Always positive. KE increases when net work done is positive.
Net work done on a body equals change in its kinetic energy. Applies to all forces (conservative and non-conservative). Valid in all inertial reference frames.
Energy possessed by a body due to its position or configuration. Associated with conservative forces. Can be negative, zero, or positive depending on reference point chosen.

A force for which work done is path-independent and depends only on initial and final positions. Work done in closed path is zero. Mechanical energy conserved. Examples: gravity, elastic spring force, electrostatic force.
A force for which work done depends on path taken. Work done in closed path is not zero. Mechanical energy is not conserved. Examples: friction, air resistance, viscous drag.
Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed from one form to another. Total energy of an isolated system remains constant. Most fundamental law in physics.
In absence of non-conservative forces, sum of kinetic and potential energy remains constant. KE + PE = constant. Energy continuously converts between forms.
The rate at which work is done or energy is transferred. Scalar quantity. SI unit: watt (W) = joule/second. 1 horsepower = 746 watts.
The ratio of useful output to total input, expressed as percentage. Always less than 100% due to energy losses (friction, heat, sound). No machine can be 100% efficient.
In elastic collision, both momentum and kinetic energy are conserved. Total KE before collision equals total KE after collision. No energy lost to deformation or heat.
In inelastic collision, momentum is conserved but kinetic energy is not. Some KE converted to other forms. Maximum loss in perfectly inelastic collision where objects stick together.
Minimum velocity needed for object to escape gravitational field of planet without further propulsion. Independent of mass of object. Depends on mass and radius of planet.
